title: The 3 locals to make the list of world's best CEOs
text:
'Zero downtime'

The property CEO was also ranked 95th in 2016, when former Ramsay Health Care CEO Chris Rex ranked 88th.

“The main feature [of Goodman Group's success] has been the force of Greg’s personality, his infectious optimism that underpins the company. He motivates all his troops and leads from the front,” Peter Davidson, executive at investment group Pendal, told BOSS magazine after he was named a 2019 True Leader.

Mr Goodman has delivered total shareholder returns of more than 600 per cent since 2010 and he recently told The Australian Financial Review that trade wars, Brexit and unrest in Hong Kong would not dampen growth.

CSL's chief executive Paul Perreault is one of three Aussies on the world's top performing CEOs list. Wayne Taylor

CSL CEO Mr Perreault – the email-loving boss from the United States who calls Utah and Melbourne home – was ranked 83rd this year in his first appearance on the list.

CSL is the world’s fifth-largest biotech with a market capitalisation of $115 billion. With the stock price at record highs of over $250, analysts are speculating whether it can reach $300 this year.

"I have to say I’m very involved in the organisation all the time," Mr Perreault recently told the Financial Review. "There’s almost zero downtime because in a global company somebody is up every hour of the day."

Quality above profit

Sonic Healthcare CEO Dr Goldschmidt also made the cut for the first time, slotting in at 90th on the list of global CEOs after leading the company for the past 26 years.

The largest medical laboratory provider in Australasia and Europe and the third-largest in the US, Sonic's share price has climbed consistently for more than a decade and is up nearly 30 per cent this year alone.

"We make decisions that are medically based, not just financially, and we put quality ahead of profit," Dr Goldschmidt recently told the Financial Review.

Sonic Healthcare CEO Colin Goldschmidt says he puts performance above profits. Kirk Gilmour

Top of this year's global list was Jensen Huang, co-founder of tech company NVIDIA, which designs graphics processing units for gaming as well as chip units for the mobile and automotive market.

From late 2015 to late 2018 NVIDIA's stock grew 14-fold, putting the 56-year-old Mr Huang in top spot.

Salesforce.com CEO Marc Benioff was ranked 2nd while other notable entries include Adobe CEO Shantanu Narayen at 6th, Mastercard CEO Ajay Banga at 7th and Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella at 9th.

Women underrepresented

The well-regarded list relies on objective performance measures over a CEO's entire tenure and these "career numbers" tend to hold steady, explaining why 65 of last year’s best CEOs reappear.

Since 2015 the rankings have included an ESG rating, but this year the ESG weighting was increased from 20 to 30 per cent to reflect investor's greater focus on non-financial risks.

Based on financial performance alone Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos would have been the top CEO every year since 2014, but he failed to make this year’s list because of Amazon’s relatively low ESG scores.

Woman remain underrepresented, with just four female CEOs making the top 100: Nancy McKinstry from Wolters Kluwer, Lisa Su from Advanced Micro Devices, Debra Cafaro from Ventas and Marillyn Hewson from Lockheed Martin.

The list also also underscored the remarkable longevity of successful CEOs, with the best-performing CEOs in the job for an average 15 years compared to an average tenure of 7.2 years for CEOs of the S &P 500.
description: Greg Goodman, Paul Perrault and Colin Goldschmidt have made the list of world's best-performing CEOs.
